newsitem.title: UK: IRA bomb suspect to keep her baby in British jail.
newsitem.headline: IRA bomb suspect to keep her baby in British jail.

text.p: A pregnant Irish woman wanted in Germany for questioning about an IRA bomb attack at a British army base will be allowed to keep her baby with her in prison, the British prison service said on Thursday.
It said Roisin McAliskey would give birth in a hospital outside jail, in line with government procedure, and then take up residence in a special prison unit.

"It would be in the child's best interests for them both to be located in the mother and baby unit. While prison can never be an ideal place for a baby, the unit offers a reasonably relaxed regime geared to helping the emotional, physical and all-round development of the child as well as teaching parenting skills to new mothers," Alan Walker, a director of operations in the prison service, said in a statement.
The daughter of veteran Irish nationalist campaigner Bernadette McAliskey, nee Devlin, 25-year-old McAliskey is currently in Holloway jail in north London.
Germany has applied for McAliskey's extradition in connection with an Irish Republican Army mortar bomb attack on a British army base in Germany last summer.
She is due to give birth in May and has become the focus of an ardent campaign by activists seeking bail for her.
Supporters say McAliskey has been subjected to "barbaric and inhumane conditions" in prison, but the prison service says her treatment has been "appropriate and humane".
She was arrested in November in connection with the attack on a British barracks in Osnabrueck last June. McAliskey denies any link with the bombing.

The IRA called a ceasefire in its battle to oust Britain from Northern Ireland in August 1994. The truce was broken 17 months later with a series of attacks on targets in mainland Britain before the Osnabrueck attack.
